head.title: Effect of Polymer Ligand Conformation on the Self-Assembly of Block Copolymers and Polymer-Grafted Nanoparticles within an Evaporative Emulsion | Macromolecules

meta.content: Effect of Polymer Ligand Conformation on the Self-Assembly of Block Copolymers and Polymer-Grafted Nanoparticles within an Evaporative Emulsion

Precise control of spatial distribution of nanoparticles (NPs) within polymeric materials is critical to build nanostructures with programed functionalities. Herein, we systematically investigate the entropy-driven self-assembly of polystyrene-coated Au NPs (Au@PS NPs) and polystyrene-block-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) block copolymers (BCPs) within a 3D-confined emulsion system. To understand the formation principle of the hybrid particles, four different parameters are examined: (1) the molecular weight of PS ligands (N), (2) the grafting density (σ) of PS ligands, (3) the size of Au NPs (R), and (4) the molecular weight of the BCP matrix (P). Morphological transitions between alternate-layered onions, seeded onions, and crusted onions are observed by carefully manipulating these variables. To account for these phenomena, we propose a modified swelling ratio (P/NSDPB) by considering grafted polymers in the semi-dilute polymer brush (SDPB) regime as the only chains available to interact with BCP matrices. This modified parameter successfully explains the structural transitions of the hybrid particles by including the effect of the chain conformation of the grafted polymers on the hybrid particle assembly. Furthermore, the overall Au@PS NP size (d) is considered as a complementary parameter to P/NSDPB for evaluating the BCP/Au@PS interactions, and together they provide a comprehensive understanding of the hybrid particle self-assembly.

div.p:

This modified parameter successfully explains the structural transitions of the hybrid particles by including the effect of the chain conformation of the grafted polymers on the hybrid particle assembly. div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Self-assembly of block copolymers (BCPs) with inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) in three-dimensionally confined emulsions is a facile and robust method to generate hybrid particles with hierarchical nanostructures.
(1−5)
The inorganic NPs endow the resulting hybrid structures with various optical, electrical, and catalytic properties,
(6−11)
while the BCP matrix serves as a flexible and stable scaffold for the NPs.
(12−14)
In particular, self-assembled BCP domains can provide well-defined nanoscale templates that dictate the spatial distribution of NPs within the hybrid particles.
(15−27)
It is critical to understand the self-assembly behavior of NPs within the BCP domains as the combination of the local distribution, orientation, and interparticle distance of NPs within a polymer matrix determines the physical properties and functionalities of such hybrid materials.
(3,28−35)

Entropic effects have a significant impact on the self-assembly of BCP/NP hybrid materials.
(36,37)
For example, the ratio of the NP size (
d
) to the associated domain size (
L
) of the BCPs is one of the most critical entropic factors. It has been demonstrated that small-sized NPs (i.e.,
d
/
L
< 0.2) can be homogeneously distributed within a BCP matrix, whereas large-sized NPs (i.e.,
d
/
L
> 0.3) tend to phase-segregate from the matrix to avoid severe conformational entropic penalties imposed on the BCP chains.
(38−42)
Recently, however, our group reported that tuning the molecular weight (
M
n
) of the polymer ligands grafted on NPs can yield hierarchically structured BCP/NP hybrid particles, which cannot be explained solely in terms of
d
/
L
-dependent assembly behavior. When symmetric polystyrene-
block
-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-
b
-P4VP) and PS-coated Au NPs (
[email protected]
NPs) were co-assembled, the Au NPs coated with relatively low
M
n
PS ligands were segregated to the surface or central regions of the BCP particles. However, the Au NPs coated with higher
M
n
ligands were accommodated within PS domains of the BCP particles despite their very large
d
/
L
value (>1), producing non-conventional alternate-layered onion (ALO)-like particles.
(43)
This phenomenon was attributed to the different entropic interactions between the BCP chains and grafted polymers on the NP surface depending on the
M
n
of the grafted polymers. It has been reported that decreasing a swelling ratio, defined as the ratio of the
M
n
of the homopolymer matrix (
P
) to the
M
n
of the grafted polymer (
N
), enhances the entropic interactions between the grafted and matrix polymers, promoting uniform NP dispersions within the homopolymer matrix.
(44−48)
Similarly, in our work, Au NPs with high
M
n
PS ligands facilitated entropic interactions with the PS blocks of BCPs confined within the emulsion droplet, leading to the formation of hierarchical ALO structures. While this phenomenon demonstrates the importance of the BCP/NP interfacial interactions on the morphology of the BCP hybrid particles, robust and comprehensive design rules are necessary to precisely predict and control the resulting nanostructures.

Herein, we investigate the self-assembly of PS-
b
-P4VP BCPs and
[email protected]
NPs within 3D confined particles and build a comprehensive relationship between the BCP/
[email protected]
interactions and the resulting morphology of the hybrid particles. The entropic interactions between the BCPs and
[email protected]
NPs are systematically controlled by tuning the core diameters (2
R
) of Au NPs (3.0–7.2 nm), the grafting density (σ) of PS ligands (0.8–2.3 chains nm
–2
), and the
M
n
of PS ligands (
N
= 1.8–8.0 kg mol
–1
), as well as the
M
n
of PS blocks of BCPs (
P
= 3–19 kg mol
–1
). Structural transitions between crusted onion, seeded onion, and ALO morphologies for the hybrid particles are observed by tuning each of these parameters. To explain the morphological transitions, we attempt to correlate these results to the conformational transition of grafted polymers from a concentrated polymer brush (CPB) to a semidilute polymer brush (SDPB) regime with increasing distance from the surface of the NP core, whose transitional point is influenced by
R
, σ, and
N
. As steric hindrance between polymers is significant in the CPB regime, we introduce a modified swelling ratio
P
/
N
SDPB
, where only the grafted polymers in the SDPB regime (
N
SDPB
) are considered to be responsible for the effective interaction with BCP chains. Indeed, compared with the conventional swelling ratio
P
/
N
, the redefined ratio
P
/
N
SDPB
more accurately explains the structural transitions between the ALO-, seeded onion- and crusted onion-like morphologies. These results emphasize the importance of the conformation of the grafted polymers on the curved NP surface in determining the effective interactions between the polymer-grafted NPs and BCPs and thus the resulting morphology of the hybrid particles.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Gold(III) chloride trihydrate (HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O, ≥99%), borane
tert
-butylamine complex (TBAB, 97%), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, ≥98%),
sec
-butyllithium solution (
sec
-BuLi, 1.4 M in hexane), 1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene, (tetralin, 99%), oleylamine (OAm, 70%), 1-octadecene (ODE, 90%), cyclohexane (anhydrous), and methanol (anhydrous) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Ethylene sulfide (98%) and styrene (≥99%) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used after distillation. Three different PS-
b
-P4VP BCPs: PS
3k
-
b
-P4VP
3k
(
M
n
of PS block = 3.3 kg mol
–1
,
M
n
of P4VP block = 3.1 kg mol
–1
, and dispersity (
Đ
) = 1.20), PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
(
M
n
of PS block = 9.8 kg mol
–1
,
M
n
of P4VP block = 10 kg mol
–1
, and
Đ
= 1.08), and PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
(
M
n
of PS block = 19 kg mol
–1
,
M
n
of P4VP block = 22 kg mol
–1
, and
Đ
= 1.15) were purchased from Polymer Source Inc.

Au NPs with an average size from 3.0 to 5.8 nm were synthesized by following a previously reported method.
(49,50)
A precursor solution was prepared by dissolving HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O (200 mg) into a mixture of OAm (20 mL) and tetralin (20 mL). The reducing agent TBAB (130 mg) was dissolved in a mixture of tetralin (2.5 mL) and OAm (2.5 mL). The precursor solution was stirred under a nitrogen flow at different temperatures of 40 °C (3.0 and 3.3 nm Au NP), 25 °C (4.6 nm Au NP), and 11 °C (5.6 and 5.8 nm Au NP) for 15 min, followed by rapid injection of the reducing solution. The solution color promptly changed from orange to deep purple, and the reaction was allowed to further proceed for 1 h before adding hexane (60 mL) to precipitate the Au NPs. The Au NPs were collected by centrifugation (8000 rpm, 2 min), washed with ethanol three times, and redispersed in tetrahydrofuran (THF) at a concentration of 5 mg/mL for ligand exchange. 7.2 nm Au NPs were obtained by a seeded growth process.
(51)
HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O (179.8 mg) was dissolved in a mixture of ODE (4.5 mL) and OAm (4.5 mL) as the precursor and then mixed with 5.6 nm Au NP seeds (80 mg) under a nitrogen flow at room temperature. The mixture was heated at 80 °C for 2 h and hexane (40 mL) was poured to quench the reaction. The product was purified and finally dispersed in THF as described above.

Thiol end-functional polystyrenes (PS-SH) with four different
M
n
values were prepared by living anionic polymerization.
(52)
sec
-BuLi solution (10.03 mL) was mixed with cyclohexane (250 mL) and heated to 35 °C. After adding styrene (15 g), the polymerization proceeded for 8 h. Subsequently, injection of ethylene sulfide (0.39 mL) induced a gradual color change from red to orange. Anhydrous methanol (5 mL) was added to quench the reaction after the solution stopped changing color. Excess methanol was added to precipitate PS-SH, which yielded a white powder (
M
n
= 1.8 kg mol
–1
and
Đ
= 1.1) after drying. Other PS-SH ligands with
M
n
of 4.3, 6.4, and 8.0 kg mol
–1
were also synthesized by the same method.

div.h3:
Preparation of PS-SH-Grafted Au NPs (
[email protected]
NPs)
div.div:
PS coating on the Au NPs was achieved by a previously reported ligand-exchange process.
(53)
A PS-SH solution in THF (2 mL) with a concentration of 7.5 μmol mL
–1
(4.6
[email protected]
with σ of 2.25 chains nm
–2
), 1.5 μmol mL
–1
(5.6
[email protected]
with σ of 0.87 chains nm
–2
), or 2.5 μmol mL
–1
(for others) was added dropwise to a Au NP solution in THF (5 mg mL
–1
, 2 mL) under sonication. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred vigorously overnight at room temperature to promote the ligand exchange process. After the addition of hexane, the
[email protected]
NPs were collected by centrifugation at 7000 rpm for 3 min and redispersed in THF after the supernatant was removed. Further centrifugation was repeated four to five times to remove excess ligands.

div.h3:
Preparation of BCP/
[email protected]
Hybrid Particles
div.div:
A mixture of PS-
b
-P4VP and
[email protected]
NPs in chloroform (5 mg mL
–1
each) was prepared under sonication for 1 min. An aqueous CTAB solution (0.5 wt %, 2 mL) was added and then the mixture was emulsified by sonication for 1 min. The emulsion was left for thorough solvent evaporation (i.e., 24 h) to promote the assembly of hybrid particles. The resulting particles were centrifuged for 5 min under 10,000 rpm and redispersed in deionized water. Residual surfactants were removed by repeating centrifugation and dispersing in water three times.

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai F20, 200 kV) was used to characterize Au NPs and hybrid particles. Size exclusion chromatography (SEC) measurements on
M
n
and
Đ
of PS-SHs were performed by SEC with a Waters 2414 system using UV and refractive index detectors calibrated with PS standards with THF at 40 °C. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed by heating samples from 25 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min
–1
. The grafting densities of the samples were calculated using the following equation:
(53)
, where
f
PS
is the weight fraction of PS ligands,
N
A
is the Avogadro constant (6.02 × 10
23
mol
–1
), ρ is the density of Au (19.32 g cm
–3
),
d
is the average diameter of Au NPs,
M
n
is the molecular weight of PS ligands, and
f
Au
is the weight fraction of Au NPs.
f
PS
and
f
Au
were determined according to the TGA results in
Figure S1
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
A number of previous studies have reported the dispersion behavior of homopolymer-grafted NPs within a matrix consisting of the same type of polymers.
(45−48,54−59)
The assembly behavior of the NPs within the matrix can be typically explained by phase diagrams of σ versus
P
/
N
,
(55,56)
with some including
R
,
(45,57)
as these parameters are critical to determine the entropic interactions between the NPs and polymer chains.
(58)
Therefore, to systematically investigate the assembly behavior of the
[email protected]
NPs in BCP particles, a series of PS-grafted Au NPs with various
N
, σ, and
R
values were co-assembled with symmetric PS-
b
-P4VP having different
P
values (i.e., PS
3k
-
b
-P4VP
3k
(S4VP3k), PS
10k
-
b
-P4VP
10k
(S4VP10k), and PS
19k
-
b
-P4VP
22k
(S4VP19k)) by a solvent-evaporative emulsion process as shown in
Scheme 1
. Highly monodisperse Au NPs with various 2
R
values ranging from 3.0 to 7.2 nm were produced following previously reported methods (
Figure S2
).
(49,51)
PS-SH ligands with four different
N
values (i.e., 1.8, 4.3, 6.4, and 8.0 kg mol
–1
denoted as
2k
,
4k
,
6k
, and
8k
, respectively) and narrow
Đ
(<1.1) were synthesized by living anionic polymerization.
(52)
Then, PS-grafted Au NPs were prepared through a ligand-exchange process.
(50)
The
[email protected]
NPs with various
R
,
N
, and σ allow us to study the formation principles of the BCP/NP hybrid particles. For convenience, we denote the PS-grafted Au NPs as
X
@
Y
, where
X
is the diameter of Au core (unit of nm) and
Y
is
N
(unit of g mol
–1
). The BCP/
[email protected]
hybrid particles were produced using a solvent-evaporative emulsion method. Briefly, a mixture of
[email protected]
NPs and PS-
b
-P4VP in chloroform was emulsified with 0.5 wt % CTAB solution. A subsequent slow solvent evaporation process over 24 h yielded the co-assembled hybrid particles with well-ordered nanostructures. The detailed fabrication procedures are described in the
Experimental Section
.

Scheme 1. Schematic Illustration of the Fabrication of Hybrid Particles
via
an Evaporative Emulsion of
[email protected]
NPs and PS-
b
-P4VP BCPs
a

figure.p:
a
In this study, the ligand molecular weight (
N
), the grafting density (σ), and the core diameter (2
R
) of
[email protected]
NPs, as well as the molecular weight (
P
) of the PS block of symmetric PS-
b
-P4VP BCPs, are varied to tune the entropic interaction of the NPs and BCP chains.

div.div:
The swelling ratio (
P
/
N
) is one of the most crucial parameters to characterize the entropic interactions between polymer matrices and polymer-grafted NPs. It has been reported that decreasing the
P
/
N
promotes favorable interactions between the polymer matrix and grafted chains on the NPs as higher
N
ligands relieve conformational entropic penalties for matrix chains confined near NPs.
(56,60−62)
Herein, to find a comprehensive influence of
P
/
N
on the morphology of BCP/NP particles, three different PS-
b
-P4VP BCPs were employed: S4VP3k, S4VP10k, and S4VP19k (
P
= 3, 10, and 19 kg mol
–1
, respectively). In addition, four different
[email protected]
NPs with a fixed Au core size of 4.6 nm but functionalized with PS ligands of different
N
s (
N
= 2, 4, 6, and 8 kg mol
–1
) were used (
Figure S3
). As shown in
Figure
1
and
Figure S4
, three different types of particle morphologies were observed depending on the BCP/
[email protected]
combination (detailed information regarding the hybrid particles is summarized in
Table S1
). Combined with cross-sectional TEM images of representative hybrid particles in
Figure S5
, the location of
[email protected]
NPs is clarified. For the crusted onion,
[email protected]
NPs were located at the particle surface (
Figure S5a
). Within seeded onions,
[email protected]
NPs were segregated at the central regions of the onion particles (
Figure S5b
). In contrast,
[email protected]
NPs are positioned within the favorable PS domains of ALO particles (
Figure S5c
). Among the S4VP10k assemblies (i.e., at a fixed
P
of 10 kg mol
–1
), the morphology of the hybrid particles transformed from crusted onion (
N
= 2k,
Figure S4a
) to seeded onion (
N
= 4k,
Figure
1
e) and then ALO (
N
= 6k in
Figure
1
i and
N
= 8k in
Figure
1
h) as the
N
value of the
[email protected]
NPs increased. Similar morphological transitions were observed with the variation of the
P
value. For example, S4VP19k/4.6
[email protected]
particles with a
P
/
N
of 4.42 yielded the crusted onion-like structures (
Figure
1
c), while the S4VP10k/4.6
[email protected]
particles with a decreased
P
/
N
of 2.28 exhibited a seeded onion-like structure (
Figure
1
e). Likewise, combinations of the 4.6
[email protected]
(
Figure
1
f,i) or 4.6
[email protected]
(
Figures S4b
and
1
h) with different BCPs showed seeded onion-to-ALO transitions as the
P
/
N
decreased. It was generally observed that the
[email protected]
NPs with relatively short PS ligands compared with the BCP chains (i.e., high
P
/
N
) segregated to the surface of the BCP particles to form the crusted onions due to limited interactions between the ligands and matrix polymer chains. In contrast, relatively long PS ligands on
[email protected]
NPs (i.e., low
P
/
N
) promote the formation of ALO structures due to their interdigitation between the PS block of the BCPs and the PS ligands on the NPs. Seeded onion-like structures were formed through moderate interactions between the
[email protected]
NPs and BCPs that prevent
[email protected]
NPs from segregating to the BCP particle surface but are insufficient to incorporate NPs within each PS layer.
(43)
However, the morphologies of the BCP/
[email protected]
particles could not be predicted solely based on their
P
/
N
values. For example, the S4VP3k/4.6
[email protected]
particle showed the crusted onion despite having a smaller
P
/
N
of 1.83 than the S4VP10k/4.6
[email protected]
(
P
/
N
= 2.28), S4VP19k/4.6
[email protected]
(
P
/
N
= 2.38), and S4VP19k/
[email protected]
particles (
P
/
N
= 2.97), which yielded seeded onions (
Figures
1
b,e,
S4b
, and
1
f). Therefore, another design rule is required to accurately account for the
[email protected]
/BCP’s interactions and their resulting morphologies.

div.div:
To reach a better understanding of the co-assembly behavior of the
[email protected]
NPs and BCPs within the hybrid particles, we carefully considered the PS ligand conformation on the NP surface. For polymer-grafted NPs with a sufficiently high σ, the polymer brushes tethered on the spherical NP can be divided into two regimes as depicted in
Figure
2
b: highly extended polymer brushes, which are designated as CPBs, and SDPBs with relatively relaxed chain conformations further away from the curved surface.
(63)
In the CPB regime, the dense packing of polymer chains prevents the interpenetration of the polymer matrix.
(43,50,64)
In contrast, the brushes in the SDPB regime have sufficient volume to allow for the penetration of the BCP matrix chains due to their reduced chain crowding. We speculated that the discrepancy between the morphological transitions and the
P
/
N
values stemmed from the differences in the chain conformation of the PS ligands for the 4.6
[email protected]
with other
[email protected]
NPs. The majority of the 2k PS ligands are expected to lie within the CPB regime and, thus, be unable to interact with PS domains of the BCPs, whereas higher
N
values enlarge the SDPB regime, enhancing their interactions with the BCP chains. To demonstrate this point, we quantified the fraction of the ligand length in each regime by using the theoretical model proposed by Ohno et al.
(63)
The critical radius (
R
c
) for the CPB to SDPB transition can be calculated as follows
(1)

l
0

v
is the excluded volume parameter. For PS ligands,

0
= 0.252 nm.
v
is defined as 0.5 – χ, where χ is the Flory–Huggins interaction parameter. We employed ν = 0.5, assuming a good solvent condition (χ = 0) for chloroform used in the assembly process. The number of monomers that fall in the CPB regime (
n
CPB
) can then be calculated as

and

/

In order to further validate the effect of the
P
/
N
SDPB
,
[email protected]
NPs with different
R
and σ values were investigated because both parameters have an impact on the crossover between CPB and SDPB behavior as described in
eq 1
. First, we examined the effect of the Au core size (2
R
) by using
[email protected]
NPs with the same
N
of 6k but different core sizes: 3.3
[email protected]
, 5.6
[email protected]
, and 7.2
[email protected]
Detailed information of the
[email protected]
NPs and corresponding hybrid particles are summarized in

. As shown in
Figure
3
, the co-assembly of 3.3
[email protected]
, 5.6
[email protected]

with S4VP19k led to the formation of ALO, seeded-onion, and crusted-onion particles, respectively (
Figure
3
a–c), indicating lower entropic interactions between polymer ligands and BCP chains with increasing
R
. These structural transitions can be explained by the changes of
P
/

SDPB
. For example, the
P
/

of 3.3
[email protected]
, 5.6

[email protected]
with S4VP19k increased to 3.57, 4.56, and 5.60, respectively. However, all three 3.3
[email protected]

NPs have the same

/

for the S4VP19k matrix despite their different morphologies, indicating that

(57,65,66)
As illustrated in
Figure
3
d, the chain crowding between the ligands on a small core decreases rapidly with increasing distance from the NP surface owing to the high surface curvature, thus providing a larger SDPB fraction to effectively interact with the BCP matrix. In contrast, the relatively low surface curvature of larger NPs allows for higher chain-crowding, enlarging the CPB regime, and prevents sufficient interpenetration of the BCP chains.

div.div:
Next, we analyzed how the σ value of the PS ligands on the NP affects the morphology of the BCP/
[email protected]
hybrid particles (
Figure
4
). The σ value of the
[email protected]
NPs was controlled by changing the feeding ratio of PS ligands to Au NPs during the ligand exchange process. Detailed information of
[email protected]
NPs and resulting hybrid particles are summarized in
Figure S9 and Table S4
. For the tested S4VP10k and 5.6
[email protected]
NPs, the NPs with a σ value of 1.31 chains nm
–2
were segregated in the central regions of the BCP particles, forming the seeded onions (
Figure
4
a). In contrast, the 5.6
[email protected]
NPs with lower σ of 0.87 chains nm
–2
produced the ALO particles (
Figure
4
b). This reduction in σ corresponds to a decrease in
P
/
N
SDPB
from 2.35 to 1.91. Similar σ-dependent structural transitions from ALO to seeded onions were also observed for S4VP10k/4.6
[email protected]
particles upon increasing the σ value in 4.6
[email protected]
NPs from 1.49 to 2.25 chains nm
–2
(
Figure S10
). This change of σ increased
P
/
N
SDPB
from 2.24 to 3.02. Again, the σ-dependent structural changes of the hybrid particles correlate well with the σ-dependent ligand conformation on the NP surface, influencing the entropic interaction between NPs and polymer matrices.
(44,56,67,68)
The CPB regime is enlarged with greater σ due to the increased chain crowding, therefore reducing the entropic interactions between the PS ligands and polymer matrix.

div.p:
Figure 4. Effect of the grafting density (σ) on the morphology of the PS-

-P4VP/

div.div:
As
N
SDPB
includes the effects of σ,
R
, and
N
on ligand conformation, the modified ratio
P
/
N
SDPB
more effectively predicts the hybrid particle morphology compared to
P
/
N
, especially when explaining structural changes of the BCP/NP hybrid particles with different
R
and σ. Therefore, we constructed a phase diagram by plotting
P
vs.
N
SDPB
(
Figure S11
). In general, the BCP/NP hybrid particles show transitions from crusted to seeded and ALO particles as
P
decreases or
N
SDPB
increases. However, some results still cannot be explained by
P
/
N
SDPB
. For example, in the case of
P
= 10 kg mol
–1
, the 3.0
[email protected]
NP showed an ALO structure despite having a smaller
N
SDPB
(3.05) than the 4.6
[email protected]
(
N
SDPB
= 3.24) or 5.6
[email protected]
NPs (
N
SDPB
= 4.17), both of which formed the seeded onion morphologies. This inconsistency is attributed to the impact of the overall size (
d
) of the
[email protected]
NPs on the chain conformation of the BCPs, which is not accounted in
P
/
N
SDPB
. While the
P
/
N
SDPB
only considers entropic interactions between the polymer ligands and the BCP chains, higher
d
values for
[email protected]
NPs impose a larger stretching penalty on the BCP chains. Therefore, a phase diagram for the BCP/NP hybrid particle morphologies in terms of
d
and
P
/
N
SDPB
was constructed and is shown in
Figure
5
b. Importantly, this diagram clearly shows that the
[email protected]
NPs with larger
d
values require lower
P
/
N
SDPB
ratios to form the ALO structure. For example, at
d
= 10.5 nm, ALO particles were formed at
P
/
N
SDPB
of 3.6. However, the ALO structure was not achieved at
d
> 13.7 nm, even for the smaller
P
/
N
SDPB
of 2.4. This is mainly attributed to the increased entropic penalty imposed on the stretched BCP chains to accommodate larger
[email protected]
NPs.

div.p:
Figure 5. Morphology diagrams of the hybrid particles by plotting (a)
d
vs
P
/
N
and (b)
d
vs
P
/
N
SDPB
. Blue squares (□), purple triangles (△), and red circles (○) represent crusted onion, seeded onion, and ALO structures, respectively.

div.div:
The diagram in
Figure
5
b describes the sequential transitions from ALO to seeded onion and to crusted onion particles. In contrast, several discrepancies in the BCP/NP structures are observed within a phase diagram based on
P
/
N
in
Figure
5
a (yellow circled regime). In the previous studies,
P
/
N
combined with σ or
R
successfully demonstrated the dispersion states of polymer-tethered NPs within polymer matrices.
(55,56,69,70)
However, many of these works used silica particles with σ values often less than 1 chain nm
–2
due to the low number of surface binding sites (i.e., Si atoms) to graft polymer ligands. In addition, the grafted ligands in these studies were significantly longer (>10–20 kg mol
–1
) than those in this work. Therefore, relatively low σ and high
N
grafted chains provide a large SDPB domain, with a small CPB regime. In our study, Au NPs enable dense grafting of polymer ligands, providing a considerable CPB regime on the curved NP surfaces. Neglecting the CPB regime for the densely grafted, low
N
polymer-grafted NPs may lead to overestimations of the entropic interactions between NPs and BCP matrices, which accounts for the fact that the
P
/
N
-based phase diagram fails to describe the structural transition in our study. In summary, the modified
P
/
N
SDPB
ratio accurately predicts the entropic interactions between the BCP chains and polymer ligands on the NP surfaces due to changes in ligand conformation on the NP surface, while
d
complements the influence of the overall size of the polymer-coated NPs on the stretching penalty of BCP chains. Therefore,
P
/
N
SDPB
and
d
cooperatively determine the overall interactions between the
[email protected]
NPs and the BCP matrix, thus guiding the co-assembly of
[email protected]
NPs and BCP within the hybrid particle. While the results for
P
/
N
SDPB
values over 10 are not shown in the phase diagram, previously described S4VP3k/4.6
[email protected]
(
P
/
N
SDPB
= 41.25) and S4VP10k/4.6
[email protected]
(
P
/
N
SDPB
= 122.50) particles yielded crusted onion-like particles. On the other hand, when the
P
/
N
SDPB
became significantly small (i.e., lowering the
P
/
N
SDPB
to below 0.76), the
[email protected]
NPs phase-separated from the BCP matrix, as observed for 4.6
[email protected]
and S4VP3k assemblies (
Figure S12
). This phenomenon is different from the case of the polymer-grafted NP/homopolymer matrix, as it has not been previously reported that reducing
P
of the homopolymer matrix can lead to NP segregation. In this case, the short homopolymer chains can be readily dispersed between grafted polymers on the NPs when the two polymers bear the same chemical structure. In contrast, the repulsive interaction between polymeric ligands and dissimilar blocks in BCPs might limit the degree of miscibility between BCP chains and grafted polymers, resulting in the phase separation of the two components.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, we demonstrated the impact of the ligand conformation on the curved NP surface on the entropic interaction between the
[email protected]
NPs and BCPs and, thereby, the spatial location of
[email protected]
NPs within the BCP particles. Changes of
N
,
R
, σ, and
P
induced morphological transitions of the hybrid particles between ALO, seeded onion, and crusted onion structures. The modified swelling ratio,
P
/
N
SDPB
, in which only the polymer chains in the SDPB regime are responsible for the effective interaction with the BCP chains, successfully describes the self-assembly behavior of the BCP/NP hybrid particles. This is because
P
/
N
SDPB
reflects the collective effects of
R
, σ,
N
, and
P
on the ligand chain conformation, and all these parameters significantly influence the entropic interactions with BCP chains. Furthermore, as the
d
values of NPs affect the stretching penalty imposed on BCP chains, a
P
/
N
SDPB
- versus
d-
based phase diagram successfully described the structural transitions of the hybrid particles. Our model captures the entropy-driven self-assembly behavior of BCP/NP within a 3D confined system, which will be useful for the design of hybrid materials with sophisticated nanostructures and desirable functionalities.

Recent progress in the self-assembly of block copolymers confined in emulsion droplets
Yan, Nan; Zhu, Yutian; Jiang, Wei
Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom)
(
2018
),
54
(
94
),
13183-13195
CODEN:
CHCOFS
; ISSN:
1359-7345
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. When the self-assembly of block copolymers (BCPs) occurs within a deformable emulsion droplet, BCPs can aggregate into a variety of nanoscaled particles with unique nanostructures and properties since the confinement effect can effectively break the symmetry of a structure. On the other hand, the self-assembled BCP particles can serve as the scaffolds to further direct the spatial arrangement of functional inorg. nanoparticles (NPs) via co-assembly or in situ deposition, thus generating diverse hybrid functional BCP/NP composites with enhanced properties. Here, we summarize the recent progress in the confined self-assembly of BCPs within the emulsion droplet and spatial arrangement of NPs on the resulting BCP scaffolds. This feature article focuses on the influence of multiple factors, including the oil/water interfacial properties, confinement degree, intrinsic properties of BCPs, additives, pH value, and temp., on the nanostructures of the self-assembled BCP particles as well as the spatial arrangement of NPs on the BCP scaffolds from both expt. and simulation studies.

Fabrication of Superparamagnetic Cobalt Nanoparticles-Embedded Block Copolymer Microcapsules
Qiao, Ru; Zhang, Xiao Li; Qiu, Ri; Li, Yan; Kang, Young Soo
Journal of Physical Chemistry C
(
2007
),
111
(
6
),
2426-2429
CODEN:

; ISSN:
1932-7447
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
A facile synthetic route for the prepn. of block copolymer microcapsules with cobalt magnetic nanoparticles (MPs) embedded in the polymer shells is reported. The prepn. involved 1st the Co2+ redn. to produce cobalt nanocrystals (∼13 nm in size). This was followed by the formation of thin polymeric coatings on the surface of Co nanoparticles owing to van der Waals attractive forces between the oxygen atoms in the block copolymer and the Co atoms and the self-assembly of capsule shells simultaneously. XRD, FTIR, FE-SEM, TEM, and TGA were used for the characterization of the obtained hollow microcapsules. The reaction time and copolymer concn. are the crucial factors affecting the phase of the products. The excellent dispersibility of the products in most common solvents originates from amphiphilic nature of the block copolymer. The hybrid microcapsules are superparamagnetic at room temp. under existence of MPs and could be moved and collected with an external magnetic field, which makes these products a good candidate for multifunctional directed materials in biotechnol. application.

Multicolor Emission of Hybrid Block Copolymer-Quantum Dot Microspheres by Controlled Spatial Isolation of Quantum Dots
Ku, Kang Hee; Kim, Minsoo P.; Paek, Kwanyeol; Shin, Jae Man; Chung, Sunhaeng; Jang, Se Gyu; Chae, Weon-Sik; Yi, Gi-Ra; Kim, Bumjoon J.

(

),

(
16
),
2667-2672
CODEN:
SMALBC
; ISSN:
1613-6810
.
(
Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
)
Multi-color emitting hybrid block copolymer-quantum dot (BCP-QD) microspheres were developed through control of the locations of different-colored QDs in BCP micelles. QDs were incorporated successfully into the core of the polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) micelles by use of 3-n-pentadecyphenol (PDP) as a small mol. linker. BCP microspheres with raspberry-like surface structures were prepd. by an evapn.-induced self-assembly from an emulsion. When two different types of QDs were independently incorporated into isolated micelles of s-BQ microspheres, FRET between the two types of QDs was completely suppressed because the thickness of the protective micellar corona was greater than the Forster radius. In contrast, when both the blue and the orange QDs were concurrently incorporated into the same P4VP micelle cores, a strong orange emission was obsd. due to FRET from the blue to orange QDs. Through the isolated BCP micelles, ratiometric control of different-colored QDs can display a wide range of color while still maintaining the original luminescence intensity. This approach can be extended to various hybrid colloidal particle systems with concurrent organization of multiple functionalities, such as plasmonic and magnetic nanoparticles, thus allowing promising applications in photonics, optoelectronics, and sensors.

We report a facile strategy to synthesize amphiphilic gold (Au) nanoparticles functionalized with a multilayer, micelle-like structure consisting of a Au core, an inner hydroxylated polyisoprene (PIOH) layer, and an outer polystyrene shell (PS). Careful control of enthalpic interactions via a systematic variation of structural parameters, such as no. of hydroxyl groups per ligand (NOH) and styrene repeating units (NPS) as well as areal chain d. of ligands on the Au-core surface (Σ), enables precise control of the spatial distribution of these nanoparticles. This control was demonstrated in a lamellae-forming poly(styrene-b-2-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P2VP) diblock copolymer matrix, where the favorable hydrogen-bonding interaction between hydroxyl groups in the PIOH inner shell and P2VP chains in the PS-b-P2VP diblock copolymer matrix, driving the nanoparticles to be segregated in P2VP domains, could be counter balanced by the enthalphic penalty of mixing of the PS outer brush with the P2VP domains. By varying NOH, NPS, and Σ, the nanoparticles could be positioned in the PS or P2VP domains or at the PS/P2VP interface. In addn., the effect of additives interfering with the hydrogen-bond formation between hydroxyl groups on Au nanoparticles and P2VP chains in a diblock copolymer matrix was investigated, and an interesting pea-pod-like segregation of Au nanoparticles in PS domains was obsd.

Interface engineering of evaporative emulsion droplets contg. block copolymers (BCPs) provides an effective route to generate nonspherical particles. Here, we demonstrate the impact of length-controlled nanorods (NRs) on the interfacial properties of BCP emulsions to produce anisotropic BCP particles. A series of lamellae- and cylinder-forming polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) and a series of NRs with different lengths (l) are coassembled, and selective arrangement of the NRs on the P4VP domain at the particle surface enables the prodn. of striped football (prolate) and convex lens-shaped (oblate) particles. In particular, the ratio of the NR length to the size of the NR-hosting domain (l/L), which is varied from 0.07 to 3.60, is the key parameter in detg. the location of the NRs in the BCP particles as well as the final particle shape. The oblate particles are generated only in the range of 0.36 ≤ l/L ≤ 0.96, whereas the prolate particles are produced for much wider range of l/L ≥ 0.83 without upper limit. This difference is attributed to larger entropic penalty for the NRs confined within the P4VP cylinders than the entropic penalty for those within the lamellae. To better understand and support our exptl. observations, we performed dissipative particle dynamics simulation and calcd. the free energy for the NR/BCP assembly within the emulsion droplets.

In recent decades, extensive studies have been devoted to assembling nanoparticles (NPs) into various ordered structures to achieve novel optical properties. However, it still remains a challenging task to assemble NPs into cyclic one-dimensional (1D) shapes, such as rings and frames. Herein, we report a directed assembly method to precisely assemble NPs into well-defined, free-standing frames using polymer single crystals (PSCs) as the template. Preformed poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) single crystals were used as the template to direct the crystn. of block copolymer (BCP) poly(ethylene oxide)-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PEO-b-P4VP), which directs the gold NPs (AuNPs) to form AuNP frames. By controlling the PSC growth, we were able to, for the first time, precisely tune both the size and width of the AuNP frame. These novel AuNP frames topol. resemble NP nanorings and cyclic polymer chains, and show unique surface plasmon resonance (SPR) behaviors.

Deformable full-color light-emitting diodes with ultrafine pixels are essential for wearable electronics, which requires the conformal integration on curvilinear surface as well as retina-like high-definition displays. However, there are remaining challenges in terms of polychromatic configuration, electroluminescence efficiency and/or multidirectional deformability. Her,e we present ultra-thin, wearable colloidal quantum dot light-emitting diode arrays utilizing the intaglio transfer printing technique, which allows the alignment of red-green-blue pixels with high resolns. up to 2,460 pixels per in. This technique is readily scalable and adaptable for low-voltage-driven pixelated white quantum dot light-emitting diodes and electronic tattoos, showing the best electroluminescence performance (14,000 cd m-2 at 7 V) among the wearable light-emitting diodes reported up to date. The device performance is stable on flat, curved and convoluted surfaces under mech. deformations such as bending, crumpling and wrinkling. These deformable device arrays highlight new possibilities for integrating high-definition full-color displays in wearable electronics.

Minimizing the use of Pt catalysts in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is important, considering its high price and scarcity. Herein, we demonstrate novel catalysts for PEMFCs with exceptionally high mass activity and durability, in which block copolymer-based carbon supports are loaded with an ultra-small amt. of Pt. The mass activity measured after 30 000 cycles of single cell tests was 0.81 A mgPt-1 at 0.9 V, which is the highest performance reported to date. The newly developed catalyst yielded nearly the same power d. as that of the com. Pt/C, even with 1/20 of the Pt usage. The carbon supports were prepd. by carbonizing crosslinked domains of block copolymer particles selectively, resulting in mesoporous carbon particles with ~ 25 nm pores. When Pt was deposited, thin carbon shells were formed encapsulating PtFe nanoparticles, catalyzing the oxygen redn. reaction efficiently with high durability.

The assembly and direct imaging of ferromagnetic nanoparticles into one-dimensional mesostructures (1-D) are reported. Polymer-coated ferromagnetic colloids (19 nm, 24 nm) were assembled at a crosslinkable oil-water interface under both magnetic field induced and zero-field conditions and permanently fixed into 1-D mesoscopic polymer chains (1-9 μm) in a process referred to as Fossilized Liq. Assembly (FLA). In the FLA process, nanoparticle chains were fixed at the oil interface through photopolymn., enabling direct visualization of organized mesostructures using at. force microscopy. Using the FLA methodol., we systematically investigated different conditions and demonstrated that dispersed ferromagnetic colloids possess sufficient dipolar interactions to organize into mesoscopic assemblies. Application of an external magnetic field during assembly enabled the formation of micron-sized chains which were aligned in the direction of the applied field. This universal methodol. is an attractive alternative technique to cryogenic transmission electron microscopy (cryo-TEM) for the visualization of nanoparticle assembly in dispersed org. media.

A simple yet versatile soln.-based process to produce colloidal silica hexapods is developed in which various shapes of silica rods are grown on the faces of cubes in a controlled manner. In the presence of hematite cubic particles, water droplets nucleate on the surface of hematite by phase sepn. in pentanol. By adjusting the water concn., six droplets can form on each face of the hematite cube. A silica precursor is then administered into the system, which gradually diffuses into the water droplets through the oil phase. Within the droplets, hydrolysis and condensation of the precursors take place, leading to formation of silica rods. As a result, silica hexapods on a magnetic hematite cubic seed are produced. Furthermore, when the emulsions are aged at 60 °C prior to the silica growth, the water content in the soln. decreases gradually due to evapn. and spiky sharp hexapods are produced. On the other hand, when organosilane precursor is added, pancake-like hexapods are formed due to the redn. of interfacial tension. These colloidal hexapods can further be utilized as new building blocks for self-assembly to construct functional materials or as a model system to understand collective behaviors.

Compartmentalization is ubiquitous to many biol. and artificial systems, be it for the sep. storage of incompatible matter or to isolate transport processes. Advancements in the synthesis of sequential block copolymers offer a variety of tools to replicate natural design principles with tailor-made soft matter for the precise spatial sepn. of functionalities on multiple length scales. Here, we review recent trends in the self-assembly of amphiphilic block copolymers to multicompartment nanostructures (MCNs) under (semi-)dil. conditions, with special emphasis on ABC triblock terpolymers. The intrinsic immiscibility of connected blocks induces short-range repulsion into discrete nano-domains stabilized by a third, sol. block or mol. additive. Polymer blocks can be synthesized from an arsenal of functional monomers directing self-assembly through packing frustration or response to various fields. The mobility in soln. further allows the manipulation of self-assembly processes into specific directions by clever choice of environmental conditions. This review focuses on practical concepts that direct self-assembly into predictable nanostructures, while narrowing particle dispersity with respect to size, shape and internal morphol. The growing understanding of underlying self-assembly mechanisms expands the no. of exptl. concepts providing the means to target and manipulate progressively complex superstructures.

Three-dimensional (3D) assemblies of metal nanoparticles are promising materials for plasmonic materials. Metal nanoparticles have unique surface plasmon resonances, ranging from UV to visible light wavelengths, depending on their metal species, size, and shape. The arrangements and spacing of the nanoparticles also strongly affect the plasmonic properties. The microphase sepn. of block copolymers can create a nanoscopic periodic structure, where metal nanoparticle assemblies are arranged along the microphase sepn. structure. In this paper, we construct 3D Au nanoparticle assemblies embedded in the microphase sepn. structures of confined block copolymers, in the pores of inverse opals. Polymer-stabilized Au nanoparticles were synthesized, and submicrometer poly(styrene) (PS) colloidal crystals were prepd. using a simple coating method. After molding a PS colloidal crystal with poly(vinyl alc.) (PVA), block copolymers and Au nanoparticles were introduced into the PVA inverse opal from soln. The inner nanostructures were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

Block copolymer (BCP) self-assembly is one of the most versatile concepts for the bottom-up design of functional nanostructures in materials science, nanomedicine and nanotechnol. While BCPs have been extensively studied regarding their microphase sepn. in bulk and the self-assembly in soln., only recently BCPs were investigated for their ability to form internally ordered microparticles. In this review, we discuss two emerging concepts: (i) the microphase sepn. of BCPs in the spherical confinement of evapg. emulsion droplets and (ii) the self-assembly of highly asym. BCPs under concd. conditions. While the first concept yields solid and compact multicompartment microparticles suited for the synthesis of shape-anisotropic nanoparticles, photonic colloids, and actuators, the latter produces highly regular porous microparticles with exceptional interfacial area (BCP cubosomes and hexosomes). Despite distinct differences in the origin of both fields, commonalities in shape and morphol. suggest an underlying formation mechanism that may link both research directions.

Monodisperse colloidal particles of polystyrene-b-polybutadiene (PS-b-PB) block copolymers (BCPs) were successfully prepd., in which uniform emulsions contg. BCPs were first generated by cross-flow membrane emulsification using tubular Shirasu porous glass (SPG) membrane, and then unique internal nanostructures were developed by controlled evapn. of solvent inside emulsion. The diam. of those BCP particles could be controlled from 200 nm to 5 μm by tuning the pore diam. of the membrane. With sym. BCPs, onion-like nanostructures inside particles were formed. Coiled cylinders in the BCP particles were also developed by adding homopolymers, in which the assembled BCP structure is strongly dependent on the particle size, demonstrating the importance of our membrane method in generating monodisperse BCP particles. Further investigation of process parameters showed that for a given pore diam., the operation pressure (P) and surfactant concn. were crit. parameters for narrow size distribution of the particles. Uniform emulsions were produced when the ratio of the operation pressure to the crit. pressure (P/Pc) was less than 4.33. In addn., uniformly sized, hierarchically structured particles of BCPs and nanoparticles (NPs) were produced, in which oleylamine-coated, 3 nm sized Au NPs were incorporated selectively into the PB domains inside the particles.

A review. Confined assembly of block copolymers (BCPs) is receiving increasing attention due to the ability to create unconventional morphologies that cannot be obsd. in the corresponding bulk systems. This effect is further driven by the simplicity and versatility of these procedures for controlling the shape of particles prepd. by 3D soft confinement of BCPs in emulsions. By taking advantage of a mobile emulsion interface, the one-step formation of nonspherical BCP particles through spontaneous deformation is possible with design principles and theor. models for controlling shape/nanostructure now being established. This Viewpoint highlights strategies for shape tuning of BCP particles, currently accessible shapes, their controllability, and potential application. The emergence of 3D soft confinement of BCPs and related theory is overviewed with a focus on current strategies, types of nonspherical shapes achieved, and structure-property relationships for nonspherical BCP particles. Finally, the applications and future perspectives for these materials are discussed.

A review. This Perspective outlines recent advances concerning the formation and potential uses of block copolymer micelles, a class of soft matter-based nanoparticles of growing importance. As a result of rapidly expanding interest since the mid 1990s, substantial advances have been reported in terms of the development of morphol. diversity, structural complexity, control over micelle dimensions, scale up, and applications in a range of areas from nanocomposites to nanomedicine.

We report on the evapn.-induced confinement assembly (EICA) of polystyrene-b-polybutadiene-b-poly(Me methacrylate) (PS-b-PB-b-PMMA, SBM) triblock terpolymers into multicompartment microparticles and follow their morphol. evolution during solvent-adsorption annealing. We initially obtain elliptic microparticles with axially stacked PS/PB/PMMA morphol. using cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as surfactant. Exchanging the surfactant to poly(vinyl alc.) (PVA) during solvent vapor annealing with chloroform (CHCl3), PMMA preferentially interacts with the interface, and microparticles change their shape into spheres with concentric morphol. Surprisingly, this transformation initiates at both poles of the microparticles simultaneously and then proceeds toward the equator, resulting in particles with inner morphol. and patchy topog. We obsd. this evolution for different PB fractions, suggesting the mechanism to be more general and the EICA process to be a suitable method to generate patchy particle surfaces.

Micrometer-sized, monodisperse, "onionlike" multilayered polystyrene-block-poly(Me methacrylate) (PS-b-PMMA, vol. fraction of PS segment in the block copolymer; fPS ≈ 0.5) particles and PS/PS-b-PMMA/PMMA composite particles with different layer thicknesses (D) were successfully prepd. by slow release of toluene by evapn. from polymer/toluene droplets dispersed in aq. media formed using the membrane emulsification method. D is defined as one periodicity consisting of single PS and PMMA layers. The effects of no.-av. mol. wt. (Mn of PS-b-PMMA ≈ (7.8-29.0) × 104 g mol-1) and vol. fraction of PS-b-PMMA (PS/PS-b-PMMA/PMMA = 0/10/0-4.5/1/4.5, vol./vol./v) on the D of multilayered particles were investigated. The D value increased with an increase in Mn to the 2/3 power, in agreement with theory established in polymer blend film systems. PS (Mn ≈ (1.1-48.9) × 104 g mol-1)/PS-b-PMMA (Mn ≈ 29.0 × 104 g mol-1, fPS ≈ 0.5)/PMMA (Mn ≈ (1.3-46.9) × 104 g mol-1) composite particles with various vol. fractions were also prepd. When the mol. wts. of the homopolymers were lower than those of the corresponding polymer segments in the block copolymer, multilayered structures were obsd. even at a low vol. fraction of the block copolymer. On the other hand, when they were higher, microphase and macrophase-sepd. structures coexisted in all vol. fractions. The D of multilayered particles contg. low mol. wt. homopolymers was proportional to the -1/3 power of the vol. fraction of the block copolymer consistent with the theory of the polymer blend film systems, indicating that the D is controllable by proper selection of the exptl. conditions.

The formation of nanostructured shape anisotropic nanoparticles from poly(ferrocenylsilane)-b-poly(2-vinylpyridine) (PFS-b-P2VP) block copolymers is presented. Ellipsoidal particles with an axially stacked lamellar structure and nanosheets with a hexagonal structure of PFS cylinders are obtained under neutral wetting conditions through the use of a mixed surfactant system during self-assembly. In contrast to traditional systems, the resulting particle structure is strongly influenced by crystn. of the PFS domains under colloidal confinement with lamella-forming PFS-b-P2VP block copolymers leading to cylindrical morphologies. A blending approach was developed to control this morphol. change and by the addn. of PFS homopolymers, ellipsoidal particles with a lamellar structure could also be obtained. Ultimately, the spatial control over two orthogonal functionalities was exploited to demonstrate morphol. transitions for nanosheets upon the exposure to methanol as solvent for P2VP and FeCl3 as a redox stimulus, opening up a variety of applications in the field of stimuli-responsive materials.

A robust strategy is developed for prepg. light-responsive block copolymer (BCP) particles in which shape and color can be actively controlled with high spatial and temporal resoln. The key to achieving light-responsive shape transitions of BCP particles is the design and synthesis of surfactants contg. light-active groups (i.e., nitrobenzyl esters and coumarin esters) that modulate the amphiphilicity and interfacial activity of the surfactants in response to light of a specific wavelength. These light-induced changes in surfactant structure modify the surface and wetting properties of BCP particles, affording both shape and morphol. transitions of the particles, for example from spheres with an onion-like inner morphol. to prolate or oblate ellipsoids with axially stacked nanostructures. In particular, wavelength-selective shape transformation of the BCP particles can be achieved with a mixt. of two light-active surfactants that respond to different wavelengths of light (i.e., 254 and 420 nm). Through the use of light-emitting, photoresponsive surfactants, light-induced changes in both color and shape are further demonstrated. Finally, to demonstrate the potential of the light-triggered shape control of BCP particles in patterning features with microscale resoln., the shape-switchable BCP particles are successfully integrated into a patterned, free-standing hydrogel film, which can be used as a portable, high-resoln. display.

A reversible transformation of overall shape and internal structure as well as surface compn. of nanostructured block copolymer particles is demonstrated by solvent-adsorption annealing. Polystyrene-b-poly-(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) pupa-like particles with PS and P4VP lamellar domains alternatively stacked can be obtained by self-assembly of the block copolymer under 3D soft confinement. Chloroform, a good solvent for both blocks, is selected to swell and anneal the pupa-like particles suspended in aq. media. Reversible transformation between pupa-like and onion-like structures of the particles can be readily tuned by simply adjusting the particle/aq. soln. interfacial property. Interestingly, poly(vinyl alc.) (PVA) concn. in the aq. media plays a crit. role in detg. the particle morphol. High level of PVA concn. is favorable for pupa-like morphol., while extremely low concn. of PVA is favorable for the formation of onion-like particles. Moreover, the stimuli-response behavior of the particles can be highly suppressed through selective growth of Au nanoparticles within the P4VP domains. This strategy provides a new concept for the reversible transformation of nanostructured polymer particles, which will find potential applications in the field of sensing, detection, optical devices, drug delivery, and smart materials fabrication.

Self-assembly of block copolymers in three-dimensional (3D) soft confinement has become a versatile method for the prepn. of functional microparticles. While the morphol. behavior of AB diblock copolymers in confinement is fairly well understood, only sporadic examples exist for ABC triblock terpolymers. Considering the more complex morphol. space of terpolymers, a better understanding of their behavior in confinement would be desirable to gain access to a large variety of multicompartment microparticles (MMs). Here, we report on the 3D confinement self-assembly of MMs from a library of polystyrene-block-polybutadiene-block-poly(tert-Bu methacrylate) (PS-b-PB-b-PT or SBT) triblock terpolymers with widely different block vol. fractions (.vphi.), which can be mapped into a ternary microphase diagram. Equal-sized end blocks (.vphi.S ≈ .vphi.T) result in MMs with lamella-lamella (LL) morphol. and a tulip-bulb or pinecone shape, irresp. of .vphi.B. For asym. end blocks (.vphi.S > .vphi.T) at low .vphi.B, prolate ellipsoids develop a hexagonally packed core-shell ring (HCR) morphol., which changes with increasing .vphi.B to a transition structure between HCR and a concentric sphere-in-lamella (CSL) morphol. Further increasing .vphi.B to .vphi.S ≈ .vphi.B at low .vphi.T, the structure transforms entirely to CSL in an onion-like shape. Selective crosslinking of the PB middle block and disassembly of the MMs give access to a variety of nanostructures such as core-shell rings, Janus nanobowls, and nanocups.

Metallic nanoparticles that absorb and conc. light are leading to greater efficiencies in nanophotonic devices. By confining Au nanorods (Au NRs) in a polymer film, the authors can control their spacing and orientation and, in turn, the absorption and polarization characteristics of the nanocomposite. The authors systematically increase the vol. fraction of Au NRs (φrod) (aspect ratio ν = 3.3) while maintaining a uniform dispersion. As φrod increases from 1 to 16 vol.%, the spacing between rods decreases from 120 to 20 nm and scales as φrod-0.4. Simultaneously, the local 2-dimensional orientational order parameter increases linearly with φrod, although the rods are globally isotropic. The Au NR dispersion depends on the enthalpic interactions between poly(ethylene glycol) brush grafted to the Au NRs and the poly(Me methacrylate) matrix chains. Also, the plasmon resonance exhibits a red shift with increasing φrod, and coupling is obsd. for sepns. up to 70 nm. Because NR spacing and orientation can be finely controlled using polymer matrix, these films are ideally suited for understanding fundamental behavior (e.g., plasmon coupling) as well as practical devices (e.g., solar cells).

The ability to dynamically organize functional nanoparticles (NPs) via the use of environmental triggers (temp., pH, light, or solvent polarity) opens up important perspectives for rapid and convenient construction of a rich variety of complex assemblies and materials with new structures and functionalities. Here, we report an unconventional strategy for crafting stable hairy NPs with light-enabled reversible and reliable self-assembly and tunable optical properties. Central to our strategy is to judiciously design amphiphilic star-like diblock copolymers comprising inner hydrophilic blocks and outer hydrophobic photoresponsive blocks as nanoreactors to direct the synthesis of monodisperse plasmonic NPs intimately and permanently capped with photoresponsive polymers. The size and shape of hairy NPs can be precisely tailored by modulating the length of inner hydrophilic block of star-like diblock copolymers. The perpetual anchoring of photoresponsive polymers on the NP surface renders the attractive feature of self-assembly and disassembly of NPs on demand using light of different wavelengths, as revealed by tunable surface plasmon resonance absorption of NPs and the reversible transformation of NPs between their dispersed and aggregated states. The dye encapsulation/release studies manifested that such photoresponsive NPs may be exploited as smart guest mol. nanocarriers. By extension, the star-like block copolymer strategy enables the crafting of a family of stable stimuli-responsive NPs (e.g., temp.- or pH-sensitive polymer-capped magnetic, ferroelec., upconversion, or semiconducting NPs) and their assemblies for fundamental research in self-assembly and crystn. kinetics of NPs as well as potential applications in optics, optoelectronics, magnetic technologies, sensory materials and devices, catalysis, nanotechnol., and biotechnol.

The stepwise self-assembly of hollow plasmonic vesicles with vesicular membranes contg. strings of gold nanoparticles (NPs) is reported. The formation of chain vesicles can be controlled by tuning the d. of the polymer ligands on the surface of the gold NPs. The strong absorption of the chain vesicles in the near-IR (NIR) region leads to a much higher efficiency in photoacoustic (PA) imaging than for non-chain vesicles. The chain vesicles were further employed for the encapsulation of drugs and the NIR light triggered release of payloads. This work not only offers a new platform for controlling the hierarchical self-assembly of NPs, but also demonstrates that the phys. properties of the materials can be tailored by controlling the spatial arrangement of NPs within assemblies to achieve a better performance in biomedical applications.

The authors demonstrate template-guided self-assembly of Au nanoparticles into ordered arrays of uniform clusters suitable for high-performance SERS on both flat (Si or glass) chips and an optical fiber faucet. Cluster formation is driven by electrostatic self-assembly of anionic citrate-stabilized Au nanoparticles (∼11.6 nm diam.) onto 2-dimensionally ordered polyelectrolyte templates realized by self-assembly of polystyrene-block-poly(2-vinylpyridine). A systematic variation is demonstrated for the no. of particles (N ≈ 5, 8, 13, or 18) per cluster as well as intercluster sepns. (Sc ≈ 37-10 nm). Min. interparticle sepns. of <5 nm, intercluster sepns. of ∼10 nm, and nanoparticle densities on surfaces as high as ∼7 × 1011/in.2 are demonstrated. Geometric modeling is used to support exptl. data toward estn. of interparticle and intercluster sepns. in cluster arrays. Optical modeling and simulations using the finite difference time domain method are used to establish the influence of cluster size, shape, and intercluster sepns. on the optical properties of the cluster arrays in relation to their SERS performance. Excellent SERS performance, as evidenced by a high enhancement factor, >108 on flat chips and >107 for remote sensing, using SERS-enabled optical fibers is demonstrated. The best performing cluster arrays in both cases are achievable without the use of any expensive equipment or clean room processing. The demonstrated approach paves the way to significantly low-cost and high-throughput prodn. of sensor chips or 3D-configured surfaces for remote sensing applications.

The emulsion-solvent evapn. method was widely employed as a route to achieve three-dimensional confined assembly for prepg. block copolymer (BCP) microparticles. The interfacial property of emulsion droplets plays an important role in controlling the shapes and internal structures of the microparticles. In this report, we employed iron oxide nanoparticles (NPs) covered by pH-responsive poly(acrylic acid)-b-polystyrene (
[email protected]
) to control the oil/water interfacial interaction and the morphol. of the resulting polystyrene-b-poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PS-b-PDMS) microparticles. A dramatic deformation of BCP microparticles from ellipsoidal Janus pupa-like particles to spherical onion-like particles was achieved by varying the location of
[email protected]
NPs through adjusting the pH value of the aq. phase. The mechanism for the deformation was systemically investigated by varying the pH value of the aq. phase, the wt. fraction of
[email protected]
NPs in the oil phase, and the property of aq. surfactants. Moreover, these Fe3O4-loaded hybrid BCP microparticles showed morphol.-dependent T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performance, which may provide an alternative route to optimize the efficiency of MRI contrast agents.

In this paper, we report the development of a versatile platform for a highly efficient and stable graphene oxide (GO)-based optical sensor that exhibits distinctive ratiometric color responses. To demonstrate the applicability of the platform, we fabricated a colorimetric, GO-based pH sensor that responds to a wide range of pH changes. Our sensing system is based on responsive polymer and quantum dot (QD) hybrids integrated on a single GO sheet (MQD-GO), with the GO providing an excellent signal-to-noise ratio and high dispersion stability in water. The photoluminescence emissions of the blue and orange color-emitting QDs (BQDs and OQDs) in MQD-GO can be controlled independently by different pH-responsive linkers of poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) (pKa = 4.5) and poly(2-vinylpyridine) (P2VP) (pKa = 3.0) that can tune the efficiencies of Foerster resonance energy transfer from the BQDs to the GO and from the OQDs to the GO, resp. As a result, the color of MQD-GO changes from orange to near-white to blue over a wide range of pH values. The detailed mechanism of the pH-dependent response of the MQD-GO sensor was elucidated by measurements of time-resolved fluorescence and dynamic light scattering. Furthermore, the MQD-GO sensor showed excellent reversibility and high dispersion stability in pure water, indicating that our system is an ideal platform for biol. and environmental applications. Our colorimetric GO-based optical sensor can be expanded easily to various other multifunctional, GO-based sensors by using alternate stimuli-responsive polymers.

The tuning of interfacial properties at selective and desired locations on the particles is of great importance to create the novel structured particles by breaking the symmetry of their surface property. Herein, a dramatic transition of both the external shape and internal morphol. of the particles of polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) was induced by precise positioning of size-controlled Au nanoparticle surfactants (Au NPs). The size-dependent assembly of the Au NPs was localized preferentially at the interface between the P4VP domain at the particle surface and the surrounding water, which generated a balanced interfacial interaction between two different PS/P4VP domains of the BCP particles and water, producing unique convex lens-shaped BCP particles. In addn., the neutralized interfacial interaction, in combination with the directionality of the solvent-induced ordering of the BCP domains from the interface of the particle/water, generated defect-free, vertically ordered porous channels within the particles. The mechanism for the formation of these novel nanostructures was investigated systemically by varying the size and the vol. fraction of the Au NPs. Furthermore, these convex lens-shaped particles with highly ordered channels can be used as a microlens, in which the light can be concd. toward the focal point with enhanced near-field signals. And, these particles can possess addnl. optical properties such as unique distribution of light scattering as a result of the well-ordered Au cylinders that filled into the channels, which hold great promise for use in optical, biol.-sensing, and imaging applications.

A review. Nanocomposites, composed of org. and inorg. building blocks, can combine the properties from the parent constituents and generate new properties to meet current and future demands in functional materials. Recent developments in nanoparticle synthesis provide a plethora of inorg. building blocks, building the foundation for constructing hybrid nanocomposites with unlimited possibilities. The properties of nanocomposite materials depend not only on those of individual building blocks but also on their spatial organization at different length scales. Block copolymers, which microphase sep. into various nanostructures, have shown their potential for organizing inorg. nanoparticles in bulk/thin films. Block copolymer-based supramols. further provide more versatile routes to control spatial arrangement of the nanoparticles over multiple length scales. This review provides an overview of recent efforts to control the hierarchical assemblies in block copolymer-based hybrid nanocomposites.

Many macroscopic properties such as collective chiral responses enhanced by coupled plasmonic nanoparticles require complex nanostructures. However, a key challenge is to directly assemble nanosized building blocks into functional entities with designed morphols. For example, the DNA templated nanoparticle assembly has low scalability and requires aq. conditions, while other approaches such as controlled drying and polymer templating access only simple 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D structures with limited assembly patterns. Here, the authors demonstrate a new self-assembly strategy that expands the diversity of 3-D nanoparticle assemblies. By subjecting supramol. nanocomposites to cylindrical confinement, a range of new nanoparticle assemblies such as stacked rings and single and double helixes can be readily obtained with a precisely defined morphol. CD dark field scattering measurements on the single nanowire with Au helical ribbon-like assembly show chiral plasmonic response several orders of magnitude higher than that of natural chiral materials. The phase behavior of supramol. nanocomposite under geometric constraints is quite different from that of block copolymer. It depends on the complex interplay among nanoparticle packing and phase behavior of parent block copolymers under confinement and can be governed by nanoparticle diffusion.

NPs) within onion-like particles of polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP), controlled by the mol. wt. (Mn) of PS ligands. Coassembly of
[email protected]
and PS-b-P4VP through solvent-evaporative emulsions exhibits dramatic morphol. changes in the NP assemblies depending on the Mn of PS ligands: (1) addn. of low Mn (1.8 kg mol-1)
[email protected]
creates crusted onion-like hybrid particles with well-ordered hexagonal NP superlattices covering their surface; (2) in contrast, high Mn (6.4 kg mol-1)
[email protected]
segregate at PS domains of the block copolymer particles. Interestingly, these NPs form a hexagonal packing structure at the center of the PS domains, producing concentric lamellar particles with hierarchically stacked
[email protected]
in an alternate-layered onion-like structure. Finally, cryogenic electron microscopy anal. is conducted to probe the entropy-driven mechanism of the formation of these hybrid particles. These initial demonstrations of multicomponent hybrid particles with targeted spatial alignments offer new strategies to design complex nanomaterials with tailorable properties for potential technol. applications.

Composite materials consisting of nanoparticles dispersed in a polymer matrix have potential applications in a wide range of fields. Grafting polymer chains to nanoparticles is a key strategy for controlling the distribution of those nanoparticles throughout the matrix material. The particle distribution is controlled by the relative length of the matrix chains (P) to the graft chains (N) and the d. of the graft chains (σ) for particles of a given radius (R). Using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and bulk rheol. measurements, we examine the interactions between the graft and matrix chains as a function of the three key parameters: σ, P, and N. The results of these measurements are compared to ultrasmall-angle X-ray scattering (USAXS) measurements [ Macromols. 2012, 45, 4007-4011], which were used to det. the phase behavior of the particles. DSC results indicate that the matrix chains must be completely expelled from the graft layer for the autophobic transition to occur. Similar trends are obsd. from the rheol. measurements, where the extd. thickness of the graft layer correlates to changes in the glass transition temp. from DSC. Addnl. rheol. measurements demonstrate the differences in the flow behavior between sparsely and densely grafted particles over a range of shear rates. In particular, as the graft d. increases to high levels (0.5-0.7 chains/nm2), the flow behavior of well-dispersed and aggregated particles becomes increasingly similar, as the particle-particle interactions are screened by the thick graft layer.

Phase behavior of poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) tethered silica nanoparticles dispersed in PEG hosts is investigated using small-angle X-ray scattering. Phase sepn. in dispersions of densely grafted nanoparticles is found to display strikingly different small-angle X-ray scattering signatures in comparison to phase-sepd. composites comprised of bare or sparsely grafted nanoparticles. A general diagram for the dispersion state and phase stability of polymer tethered nanoparticle-polymer composites incorporating results from this as well as various other contemporary studies is presented. We show that in the range of moderate to high grafting densities the dispersion state of nanoparticles in composites is largely insensitive to the grafting d. of the tethered chains and chem. of the polymer host. Instead, the ratio of the particle diam. to the size of the tethered chain and the ratio of the mol. wts. of the host and tethered polymer chains (P/N) are shown to play a dominant role. Addnl., we find that well-functionalized nanoparticles form stable dispersions in their polymer host beyond the P/N limit that demarcates the wetting/dewetting transition in polymer brushes on flat substrates interacting with polymer melts. A general strategy for achieving uniform nanoparticle dispersion in polymers is proposed.

The wetting of poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS)-grafted silica spheres (PDMS-g-silica) is connected to their depletion re-stabilization in semidilute and concd. PDMS/cyclohexane solns. A wetting diagram of chem. identical graft and free homopolymers predicts stability of hard, semisoft, and soft spheres as a function of the bulk free polymer vol. fraction, graft d., and the graft and free polymer chain lengths. The transition between stable and aggregated regions is detd. optically and using dynamic light scattering. The point of demarcation between the regions occurs when the graft and free polymer chains are equal in length. When graft chains are longer than free chains, the particles are stable; in contrast, the particles are unstable when the opposite is true. The regions of particle stability and instability are corroborated with theor. self-consistent mean-field calcns., which show that the grafted brush is responsible for particle dispersion in the complete wetting region and that there is aggregation in the incomplete wetting region. Depletion re-stabilization depends on the interfacial properties of the nanoparticles in semidilute and concd. polymer solns.

We systematically examd. the polymer-mediated interparticle interactions between polymer-grafted nanoparticles (NPs) within chem. identical homopolymer matrixes through exptl. and computational efforts. In expts., we prepd. thermally stable gold NPs grafted with polystyrene (PS) or poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA), and they were mixed with corresponding homopolymers. The nanocomposites are well dispersed when the mol. wt. ratio of free to grafted polymers, α, is small. Such aggregation of NPs at large α has been understood as an autophobic dewetting behavior of free homopolymers on brushes. In order to theor. investigate this phenomenon, we calcd. two particle interaction using SCF theory (SCFT) with our newly developed numerical scheme, adopting two-dimensional finite vol. method (FVM) and multi-coordinate-system (MCS) scheme which makes use of the reflection symmetry between the two NPs. It was found that increasing α is the most efficient method for promoting autophobic dewetting phenomenon, and the attraction keeps increasing up to α = 20. At small α values, high polydispersity in brush may completely nullify the autophobic dewetting, while at intermediate α values, its effect is still significant in that the interparticle attractions are heavily reduced. Our calcn. also revealed that the grafting type is not a significant factor affecting the NP aggregation behavior. The simulation result qual. agrees with the dispersion/aggregation transition of NPs found in our expts.

Nanocrystal (NC) solids are an exciting class of materials, whose phys. properties are tunable by choice of the NCs as well as the strength of the interparticle coupling. One can consider these NCs as "artificial atoms" in analogy to the formation of condensed matter from atoms. Akin to at. doping, the doping of a semiconducting NC solid with impurity NCs can drastically alter its electronic properties. A high degree of complexity is possible in these artificial structures by adjusting the size, shape, and compn. of the building blocks, which enables "designer" materials with targeted properties. Here, we present the doping of the PbSe NC solids with a series of AuxAg1-x alloy nanoparticles (NPs). A combination of temp.-dependent elec. conductance and Seebeck coeff. measurements and room-temp. Hall effect measurements demonstrates that the incorporation of metal NPs both modifies the charge carrier d. of the NC solids and introduces energy barriers for charge transport. These studies point to charge carrier injection from the metal NPs into the PbSe NC matrix. The charge carrier d. and charge transport dynamics in the doped NC solids are adjustable in a wide range by employing the AuxAg1-x NP with different Au:Ag ratio as dopants. This doping strategy could be of great interest for thermoelec. applications taking advantage of the energy filtering effect introduced by the metal NPs.

A strategy for controlling the location of gold nanoparticles within block copolymer domains through varying the surface coverage of gold nanoparticles by end-attached polymer ligands is described. Gold nanoparticles coated by short thiol end functional polystyrene homopolymers (PS-SH) (Mn = 3.4 kg/mol) are incorporated into a poly(styrene-b-2-vinylpyridine) diblock copolymer template (PS-b-P2VP) (Mn = 196 kg/mol), the P2VP block of which has a more favorable interaction with a bare gold particle surface than does the PS block. The areal chain d. of the PS-SH ligands on gold particles is varied by changing the mole ratio of PS-SH chains to gold atoms. It is found that the areal d. of PS chains on the gold particles is crit. to controlling their location in block copolymer templates. PS-coated gold nanoparticles with PS chain areal d. higher than 1.6 chains/nm2 are dispersed in PS domains of PS-b-P2VP while they are segregated along the interface between PS and P2VP domains of PS-b-P2VP for PS chain areal d. <1.3 chains/nm2. Even at extremely low grafting densities of polymer ligands, gold nanoparticles can be stabilized in soln., and self-assembly of these nanoparticles can be controlled within the block copolymer template.
